new.name: o_autotyp_MaximallyInflectedVerbSynthesis_MaximallyInflectedVerbSynthesis_VerbProsodicCoherencyNotes
short.name: TLI0441
description: autotyp_MaximallyInflectedVerbSynthesis: Verb Prosodic Coherency Notes
original.levels: 1 Watters’ (2004: 49) description suggests that prefixes or prefixes and the stem may form a tonal domain (a so-called tonal compound) that does not include the suffix string);2 Verb can have an [empty?] auxiliary to which some of the inflectional formatives attach.;3 up to 3 phonological & prosodic words:  preverb complex; verb complex; auxiliary;4 two primary stress slots can be found within a grammatical word;5 there are preverbs which can be detached from the verb;6 The verb particles seem to participate in the “verbal” processes;7 The verb is incoherent prosodically, ie wrt stress (p125f);8 The prosodic domain of a word is extended when it hosts a clitic;9 The postverbal particle is prosodically a separate word.;10 The postverbal modifiers are written and pronounced prosodically as a separate word (but see below for their clear inflectional status).;11 some parts of the syntactic word have secondary stress/are separate prosodic words;12 some particles do not participate in the tone sandhi, whereas others do;13 See below on Connective.;14 S/O agreement marker cliticizes to aspect formative, and the combination forms a phonologically separate word.;15 Provisionally judged on the basis of Borgman’s use of spaces.;16 probably not, as stress does not affect some preverbal particles, their distribution is describes as “precede the stressed portion of the complex”;17 probably not as complex predicates/compounds allow some kind of variation in the position of inflectional formatives and stress patterns;18 Preverbs, quantificational elements and incorporates are word-like (Rice 2000: 34);19 Preverbal isolating formatives (TAM, chiefly) have their own tones.  Each piece of bipartite stem has its own tone.;20 presumably;21 Prefix a- is teated as prefix because of syntax; phonologically it is free. (p141);22 Periphrastic construction consisting of two stress domains [TODO @ Manuel add pages];23 p. 62;24 One stress per inflected verb form.  (Wallis 1964.);25 One intonation counter also includes auxiliaries;26 One accent per word.;27 not discussed;28 no stress on formatives.;29 No evidence otherwise.;30 NB: Object is W. position clitic (or can be), but when it’s cliticized to the verb that is phonologically coherent.;31 MW would code it as “1”;32 MAN (mood/aspect/negation) and future are separate words.;33 Fixed ad-verbal position of clitic string; all else is affixal.;34 External sandhi shifting word boundaries cutting across the grammatical word. Noonan p. 36, 42;35 except monomoraic formatives, all formatives and semiwords (preverbs) are PrWds [p. 27ff];36 except monomoraic (AGR) formatives, all elements are isolating;37 Clitic cluster is separate from the verb with its affixes.  Arguments and others are split between clitics and affixes.;38 BB: But Okelle says it’s unclear, p. 224. More research needed.;39 as per default. The grammare is silent as to phonological wordhood.;40 as a result of separable preverbs;41 all material preceding the main V is an unfooted semi-PrWd;42 all formatives are isolating;43 agreement is through wackernagel clitics in the past and perfect tenses, the aspectual clitic does not always attach to the verb;44 6 slots, about 4 of them inflectional, are postposed isolating formatives.;45 ?
